central puzzle introduced in Book XII, c. 6?"),mdx(Question,{level:2,mdxType:"Question"},'Why does Aristotle say that there "must be a principle of the sort whose essence is actuality" (1071b19)?'),mdx(Question,{level:2,mdxType:"Question"},"What problem would occur if everything in the world only had the potentiality for motion or change, but there was no actuality that could come How so?"),mdx(Question,{level:2,mdxType:"Question"},"Can you think of an example of this kind of initiation of movement?")),mdx("h3",null,"Questions for Copleston and Russell, 'A Debate on the Argument from Contingency', pp. 5-11"),mdx("p",null,`First a note: Before getting bogged down in the details of this debate, try to step back and appreciate the whole. Whether or not you can follow every argument or claim that is made, observe in general how important the notion of "cause" or "explanation" is in this debate. Here we can we see how critical these metaphysical concepts are to foundational questions like, 'Does God exists?'. A key goal here is just to see how debates in metaphysics are in conducted in the modern area and to appreciate how the questions that occupied the ancient philosophers continue to be relevant today.`),mdx(QuestionBlock,{type:"reading-content",mdxType:"QuestionBlock"},mdx(Question,{level:1,mdxType:"Question"},"What definition of God does Copleston begin with?"),mdx(Question,{level:2,type:"reading-discussion",mdxType:"Question"},'Is this similar to or different from the "unmmoved mover" that Aristotle discovers in book 12 of the Metaphysics?')),mdx(QuestionBlock,{type:"reading-content",mdxType:"QuestionBlock"},mdx(Question,{level:1,mdxType:"Question"},`What is Copleston's definition of a "contingent being"? '),mdx(Question,{level:2,mdxType:"Question"},"What happens to our understanding of the universe if there is a sufficient reason for everything? (See page 9b.)"),mdx(Question,{level:1,mdxType:"Question"},"Why doesn't this bother Russell?"),mdx(Question,{level:2,mdxType:"Question"},"While admitting that many particular things have causes, why doesn't he think there must be a cause of the totality?"),mdx(Question,{level:3,mdxType:"Question"},'What is the argument (by analogy) about "every person who exists having a mother..." (p. 10a) and how does this support his point?'),mdx(Question,{level:3,mdxType:"Question"},"Why does he think contemporary physicists might support his point (i.e. that while there might be particular chains of cause and effect, there need not be an explanation for everything or for the totality?) (see pp. 10b, 11a, and 11b).")))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
